everybody this is mr duncan in england how are 
you today i would like to read a story to you
it's called one good turn

two young men were walking along a narrow street 
each one in turn came across an old man lying in

the gutter he was wearing tattered clothes and 
appeared cold and hungry the first man passed by

the elderly gentleman without stopping however the 
second man stopped and looked at the old man with

a sympathetic he reached into his coat pocket and 
took out some loose change that he had in there

here said the young man take this 
and buy yourself some hot food

thank you very much said the old man in a 
weak voice don't mention it replied the young

man the young man continued to walk along the 
street until he came to the corner he stopped

and turned round to his amazement the old man 
had disappeared as if he'd vanished into thin air

later that evening the young man was 
sitting at home watching the television

he was watching a program about 
people who do good turns for others

to his amazement he saw the old man whom 
he'd met earlier in the day it turned out

that the old man was in fact an actor 
dressed to appear as a homeless person

he was even more shocked to see 
himself giving the money to the

old man it turned out that the tv station 
had recorded everything that had happened

a moment later the telephone rang the young man 
hesitated for a moment and then answered it was

his mother i just saw you on television she 
screamed i'm so proud of what you did today

the young man listened to his mother's 
words of praise and smile to himself

today we are looking at an interesting part of 
english grammar i don't talk about grammar all the

time but today i'm going to briefly go through 
it because the other day i was talking about

different words that can be used with present 
tense past tense and also as past participle

and it is interesting to see that with some words 
there there are no or there are different changes

that take place so first of all let's have a look 
at the past tense when we look at the past tense

of a word well in grammar attempts expressing 
an action that has happened or a state that

previously existed is the past tense so something 
you are doing that is expressed in the future

that thing you are doing becomes the past 
because it happened already it is now

past tense and then we have past participle 
which in grammar we often use as the form

of a verb typically ending in e d and that is the 
big difference you see that is the big difference

and and often it is used in forming perfect and 
passive tenses and sometimes it is used as an

adjective as well so words that are describing an 
action normally are added with e d at the end work

worked so you worked yesterday you are talking 
about something you did you took part in

in the past so that is how 
we define a past participle

and there are words of course that we don't use 
for example formally we never say swimmed bad

very bad grammar formally we never say singed 
i singed a song and also formally we never say

ringed ringed and we are using that particular 
word as something you are doing as an action

as an action of course there is another use of 
ring if you place a ring on someone's finger

you ring someone or maybe if you put a ring on 
an animal for identification we can also say that

you ring however that does have ed at the end so 
it is possible to have that particular one there

i will point to it with my finger ringed so it 
is possible to have that but it does depend on

what use you are actually expressing at the 
time to ring something is to put a ring on

a thing however there is also another form of ring 
as well which we are going to look at right now

so we have ring rang and rung three different ways 
of expressing that word ring is the present tense

to ring to ring someone maybe you ring 
the doorbell maybe you ring your friend

you ring that person and then we have rang and 
this is where the differences come in you will see

rang is the past tense for example he rang the 
bell twice so rang expresses the past tense in

the past something we have already done and 
then we have rung which is the past participle

so you can see now the differences between 
those two words rang is the past tense rung

is the past participle for example he had rung 
the bell twice we are looking at a person doing

something and participating which is why we 
say past participle because you are doing

it you are taking part in that action and then 
oh that's interesting we have another use now

this sounds like someone's name but it 
isn't sing sang sung well first of all

sing is the present tense to sing you sing 
a song you sing out loud and then we have

the past tense which is sang we all sang together 
and then we have sung sung is the past participle

they had never sung that song before they had 
never sung that song before and finally we have

swam or swam now this is an interesting one 
because the rules of this are quite strict so

you will find quite often in english the past 
participle and the past tense of certain words

are sometimes interchangeable they can be used 
alternatively however and this is a very good

example swam or swarm well in modern english 
the uses of swam and swarm are different from

each other in the past you might not believe this 
but in the past there was no difference between

those two words a lot of people would use both 
however these days the the grammar or the rule

of the grammar has become much more strict 
it is now stricter than it was before

swam is the past tense of swim she swam across 
the lake and then we have the past participle

for example swarm is the past participle of swim 
so that must always be used if we are describing

that particular action in the past participle 
he had never swum there before he had never swum

you swum across you swim because you are taking 
part in that activity so it is interesting to

see that the past participle quite often will end 
with e d but not always it is not always the case

and that is one of the reasons why i suppose 
english is seen as a difficult language to learn

because there are some very small rules what 
i like to call micro-grammar that's my phrase

by the way i own the copyright of that phrase 
micro-grammar are things that you might miss rules

that exist in grammar that you might actually 
miss and that is one of the things that makes
learning english so difficult
